description: Topics from among the following: logic, sets, calculus, probability, history and philosophy of mathematics, game theory, geometry, and their relevance to contemporary science and society.
name: IDEAS IN MATHEMATICS

values.comments:
Ideas in Mathematics covers topics from among the following: logic, sets, calculus,
probability, history and philosophy of mathematics, game theory, geometry, and their
relevance to contemporary science and society.
Overall, students “greatly enjoyed” this course and reported being “pleasantly
surprised” by it. A few students reported particularly liking the “practical applications”
of the math concepts they were learning. Some students found that the ease of the
material and pace sometimes rendered the class uninteresting. One student noted that
some of the concepts covered were learned in “7th grade algebra.”
Students really liked Professor Liu, describing her as “excellent,” “extremely
accessible and always willing to help out.” Several students noted that Professor Liu was
very cognizant of the fact that many students did not have a strong background in math,
and she taught “at a level students could understood” and was “always available to help
with any questions.” Professor Liu read off of PowerPoint slides, which could be
“boring” for students who were familiar with the concepts, and a few noted that they did
not feel the need to attend lecture, as these PowerPoints were posted online. Professor
Liu “clearly communicated the expectations of the course,” and students knew where
they stood in the class, with respect to grades, at all times. She was also described as
“kind” and as a teacher who really cares about her students and the subject.
This course satisfies the Natural Science & Mathematics Sector requirement, and it
may also be counted toward the General Requirement in Natural Science & Mathematics.
Students described this course as being easy, and one even noted being “amazed that I get
college credit for this class.” Students, many of whom were “not mathematically
inclined,” generally took this course to fulfill their sector requirement, and they found it
to be a very enjoyable way to do so. Students received weekly homework assignments
and quizzes, which they noted were “manageable” and “very fairly graded.” Many
opportunities were also given for extra credit.

This course covers topics from among the following: logic, sets, calculus,
probability, history and philosophy of mathematics, game theory, geometry, and their
relevance to contemporary science and society.
The majority of students had an underwhelming response to this course. They
reported that it was “frustrating and disappointing” because of the lack of focus and
driving theme. In addition, since there was no syllabus, it was very difficult to keep track
of the assignments for the class.
A large majority of students were displeased with Professor Rimmer’s
performance in this class. They felt like he did not care at all. Most reported that he
often came “unprepared for class.” Since he didn’t prepare beforehand, Professor
Rimmer often made up problems on the spot, which was not efficient since he was unable
to solve them quickly and often had to backtrack. In addition, students complained that
he did not respond to emails well and was not easy to get a hold of for any additional
questions.
This class is recommended for non-majors. It fulfills the natural science and
mathematics sector.
